section.title: &kw-hos-tm; &kw-hos-version-50;: Adding a Linux for HPE Helion Compute Node

para.para: Adding a Linux for HPE Helion Compute node allows you to add additional capacity for more virtual machines.
You may have a need to add additional compute nodes for additional virtual machine capacity and these steps will help you achieve this.

sidebar.title: Prerequisites
sidebar.para: You should have one or more baremetal servers that meet the minimum hardware requirements for a compute node which are documented in the .

sidebar.title: Adding a compute node
sidebar.para: These steps will show you how to add the new Compute node to your servers.yml file and then run the playbooks that update your cloud configuration. You will run these playbooks from the lifecycle manager.

listitem.para: Log in to your lifecycle manager.
Checkout the site branch of your local git so you can begin to make the necessary edits:
Edit your ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/servers.yml file to include the details about your new compute node(s).
For example, if you already had a cluster of three compute nodes and needed to add a fourth one you would add your details to the bottom of the file in this format:
listitem.screen: # Compute Nodes - id: compute1 ip-addr: 10.13.111.137 role: COMPUTE-ROLE server-group: RACK1 nic-mapping: HP-DL360-4PORT mac-addr: f0:92:1c:05:69:98 ilo-ip: 192.168.9.4 ilo-password: password ilo-user: admin
listitem.para: You can find detailed descriptions of these fields .

important.para: You will need to verify that the ip-addr value you choose for this node does not conflict with any other IP address in your cloud environment. You can confirm this by checking the ~/helion/my_cloud/info/address_info.yml file on your lifecycle manager.

listitem.para: In your ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/control_plane.yml file you will need to check the values for member-count, min-count, and max-count. If you specified them, ensure that they match up with your new total node count. For example, if you had previously specified member-count: 3 and are adding a fourth Compute node, you will need to change that value to member-count: 4.
See for more details.
Commit the changes to git:
Run the configuration processor and resolve any errors that are indicated:
Add the new node into Cobbler:
Then you can image the node:
listitem.screen: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost bm-reimage.yml -e nodelist=<node name>
listitem.para: Before proceeding, you may want to take a look at ~/helion/my_cloud/info/server_info.yml to see if the assignment of the node you have added is what you expect. It may not be, as nodes will not be numbered consecutively if any have previously been removed. This is to prevent loss of data; the config processor retains data about removed nodes and keeps their ID numbers from being reallocated. See the Persisted Server Allocations section in for information on how this works.
Update your deployment directory:
[OPTIONAL] - Run the wipe_disks.yml playbook to ensure all of your partitions on your nodes are completely wiped prior to continuing with the installation:
Complete the compute host deployment with these two playbooks. For the last one, ensure you specify the compute hosts you are added with the --limit switch:
listitem.screen: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible/ ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts site.yml --tag "generate_hosts_file" ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts site.yml --limit <hostname>

sidebar.title: Adding a new compute host to an availability zone
sidebar.para: If you have configured availability zones for your compute hosts, you will need to do these additional steps to ensure your added compute hosts are placed into availability zones. If you skip this step, the hosts will be placed into a general nova availability zone.

listitem.para: Log in to the lifeycle manager.
Source the admin credentials to run the commands:
Get a list of availability zones to get their status:
Notice that your new compute host is showing up under the nova section.
Then run the nova-cloud-configure.yml playbook to update the Nova availability zones:
Get a list of availability zones again to verify that the new host is in the right availability zone now.
Now the new compute host is showing up under the AZ2 section.

sidebar.title: Notes about server names and IDs
sidebar.para: The server ID is a name the administrator assigns to an entry in the servers.yml file. When the configuration processor is run against the servers.yml file it will generate or update the ~/helion/my_cloud/info/server_info.yml file which contains the mapping between the entry in the servers.yml file and the machine entity created in your cloud as seen in the output from nova service-list.
For example, here is a sample of a servers.yml file:
sidebar.screen: # Compute Nodes - id: compute1 ip-addr: 10.13.111.137 role: COMPUTE-ROLE server-group: RACK1 nic-mapping: DL360p_G8_2Port mac-addr: f0:92:1c:05:69:98 ilo-ip: 10.12.11.173 ilo-password: password ilo-user: admin
sidebar.para: In the server_info.yml file it is mapped to the helion-cp1-comp0001-mgmt seen below:
sidebar.screen: compute1: failure-zone: AZ1 hostname: helion-cp1-comp0001-mgmt net_data: hed1: EXTERNAL-VM-NET: addr: null tagged-vlan: true vlan-id: 1874 GUEST-NET: addr: 10.13.111.203 tagged-vlan: true vlan-id: 1873 MANAGEMENT-NET: addr: 10.13.111.137 tagged-vlan: false vlan-id: 1872 state: allocated
sidebar.para: So when doing a nova service-list or nova hypervisor-list commands you can map the hosts shown there to items in the servers.yml file by looking for them in server_info.yml per the advice above.
